According to the Records of the Western Regions, In the past there was a recluse who built a hut and secluded himself. This person, having obtained the immortal's formula, sought a brave man, searching for him for many years without fulfilling his wish.
Later, he found a brave man who had previously worked for others for five years of hardship, and one day he disobeyed and was beaten, and again got nothing. He wept and wandered the roads.
The recluse, having seen him, ordered him to join in the journey.

From then on, he repeatedly gave him heavy gifts.
Secretly practicing kindness, he moved the man's heart. The brave man asked to repay his benefactor by offering his life.
The recluse said:
I have been seeking a brave man for many years. Fortunately, I met you. Your unusual appearance is not for any other reason. I only wish for one night of silence.
The brave man said:
'I would not avoid death, how much less would I refrain from holding my breath.'
Then he set up an altar, received the immortal methods, and was about to carry out the task. He sat waiting for the sun to set.
After dusk, each performed their duties. The recluse recited the divine incantation, and the brave man held a sharp blade.
It was about to dawn when he suddenly let out a loud cry.
At that time, fire fell from the sky, with billowing smoke and steam. The recluse quickly led the man into the pool to avoid the danger.
After a while, he asked:
'My disciple did not make a sound.
Why did you cry out in alarm?'
The brave man said:
'After receiving the order, I became dazed at midnight as if in a dream, and strange events arose again.
I saw the former host personally come to comfort and apologize. Feeling his great kindness, I could not bear to tell him.
He became enraged and ended up killing me.
I received a middle-yin body again and looked at myself with sighs, still vowing to not speak for generations to repay his great kindness.'
He then saw that he was reborn in a great Brahmin family in southern India, and even experienced the suffering of being in the womb, bearing kindness and gratitude but enduring it without speaking.

From accepting studies, to marriage, to losing parents, to having a son, he always thought of his previous kindness and endured it without speaking. The relatives in the household all found it strange.
When he was over sixty, he had a son. His wife said to him:

If you don't speak, I will kill your son.
I then thought to myself:
It has already been a lifetime. Looking at myself, I am old. This is my only young son.
So I stopped my wife from killing him and just let out a cry.
The recluse said:
It is my fault.
This is just a demon's trick.
The fierce man sighed with emotion, sad that his plan was not accomplished, and died in anger.
This means that in less than half a night, he has already gone through two lifetimes, let alone years and months.
